Rationale for Skill

  • A well-defined problem with clear requirements helps in creating a correct solution that adds value to business and helps in understanding the problem domain in a more accurate way and is the base to start any project.
  • The goal of requirements elicitation is to increase the scope,eliminate the budget overrun and helps in adequate process redesign.

Roles for Skill

  • Business Analyst
  • Business System Analyst
  • Application Architect

Work Related to Skill (Related Activities and Artifacts)

    1. Requirements gathered must be SMART (Specific, Measurable, Agreed Upon, Realistic, Time-based) and the following techniques are used.
    • Classic/Traditional Techniques:
      • Interviews - Purpose is to investigate and to get all-inclusive view of the entire system.
      • Surveys - Used to get maximum requirements from different people that may be at different locations.
      • Questionnaires - The information is obtained about the stakeholders and about the organizational environment.
    • Cognitive/Analytical Techniques:
      • Card Sorting - A technique in which cards are provided to the client according to the name of domains entity.
      • Laddering - Limited set of standards are asked to the customer and questions are set in hierarchical order.
      • Repertory Grids - Used to identify the resemblance and dissimilarity among the different domain units.
    • Modern and Group Elicitation Techniques:
      • Brain Storming - Every member can express his own idea about the product and is used to build the most important verdict about the product.
      • JAD - Joint Application Development involved available stakeholders inspecting through common conversation.
      • Prototyping - Initial product version which is prepared for getting feedback from stakeholder and making sure changes are incorporated in the next version.
    • Social Analysis:
      • Ethnography - A situation to interact with the stakeholders to check out political environment inside the organization.
      • Direct Observation - Carried out with the direct involvement of the observer in the society.
      • Passive Observation - Carried without the direct involvement of the observer in the society.
